Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: How Transnational Markets are Maintained Across Cultural and Linguistic Divides

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Globalization has presented new challenges for scientific understandings of how economic competitiveness can be achieved. Among those challenges is the need for a nuanced understanding of what emergent markets look like, and what makes them succeed or fail. Some of the most rich data sources for analyzing new markets are in sites where there are vast cultural and linguistic differences, since the networks that form in such contexts are predictably more difficult to establish. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, scientific fieldwork, explores how successful transnational markets emerge and are maintained across merchant networks.

Vivian Lu, under the supervision of Dr. Sylvia Yanagisako of Stanford University, will explore how merchants create business relationships across linguistic and cultural difference in a globalized era. In particular, this project explores how merchants successfully conduct transnational importation businesses with limited resources (for example, formal contracts, financial institutions, or translators). This project proposes that globalized commodity flows and business relations are made possible by cultural understandings of kinship, friendship, and partnership. These relationships between merchants are important to understand how cultural innovations and interpersonal trust are necessary for transnational markets to thrive. This project will investigate how transnational business experience transforms the economic possibilities and social networks of young merchants from non-elite backgrounds. Over the course of 12 months using conventional ethnographic data collection techniques, this study follows a sample of merchant returnees through regular in-depth shadowing, qualitative surveys of a broad set of merchants for contextual data, and research visits to interview the families of merchant returnees. This project will contribute to debates in economic anthropology about development and globalization, and discussions of transnationalism and labor migration. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, the project would be of benefit to development planners and policymakers struggling to understand how economic competitiveness emerges and is maintained in new markets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This doctoral dissertation research project investigated the cultural practices of Nigerian merchants actively involved in globalization between Africa, Asia, and the Middle East. Merchants from dozens of African countries find Global South trade sites – Dubai, Guangzhou, Istanbul, Ho Chi Minh, Bangkok – for their readily available wholesale markets peddling everything from chiffon blouses to metal railings to import back to their home countries. Unlike most migration oriented towards the West, young Nigerian merchants often only live in trade sites abroad briefly, and instead are continually socially and economically invested in building their lives and homes in Nigeria. This project investigated both the domestic social contexts and political consequences of how this particular group of young Igbo merchants have become significant actors and key facilitators in Nigeria’s transnational importation economy oriented towards the Global South. Through ethnographic research conducted primarily in wholesale consumer commodity markets in Lagos, the project explored how a young generation of Nigerian merchants successfully conducts transnational importation business in Asian and Middle Eastern trade sites without guidebooks, formal contracts, significant access to financial institutions, or translators. Over the course of 12 months in Lagos and Eastern Nigeria, this study followed a sample of ten young Igbo Nigerian merchant returnees through regular in-depth shadowing, qualitative surveys of a broad set of merchants for contextual data, and two research visits to Eastern Nigeria to interview the families of the ten merchant returnees. 

In a world that is facing increasing percentages of unemployed populations and the corporate consolidation of big distributors, there is a need for this investigation into how self-created and self-employed merchant work opportunities may be viable livelihoods for young people to generate regular income or even move up socio-economic classes. The research found the how historical narratives of marginalization play an important role in the public imagination about the global emergence of this mercantile generation from the turbulent petro-state of Nigeria, where Igbos are stereotyped as a commercially-inclined ethnic group with secessionist aspirations. Furthermore, the research examined how young male Igbo wholesale merchants’ individualistic yet systematic travel across the Middle East and Asia in the last two decades has decentralized and reconfigured commodity distribution in Nigeria, which was formerly monopolized by colonial and/or corporate entities importing primarily from the West.
